article.h1: 𝜸(*)⁢𝜸(*)superscript𝜸superscript𝜸bold-italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:bold-( MULOP:bold-times CLOSE:bold-) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end bold-italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:bold-( MULOP:bold-times CLOSE:bold-) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{(*)}\gamma^{(*)} reactions at high energies111submitted to proceedings of the Durham Collider Workshop, Durham, UK, 22-26 September 1999

span.span: † Department of Physics, Manchester University, UK, ad@a13.ph.man.ac.uk

div.p: The energy available for γ(*)⁢γ(*)superscript𝛾superscript𝛾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( MULOP:times CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( MULOP:times CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{(*)}\gamma^{(*)} physics at LEP2 is opening a new window on the study of diffractive phenomena, both non-perturbative and perturbative. We discuss some of the uncertainties and problems connected with the experimental measurements and their interpretation.

Diffractive phenomena occur in each of untagged, single-tagged and double-tagged photon-photon reactions via the total hadronic γ⁢γ𝛾𝛾italic-gamma italic-gamma\gamma\gamma cross-section, σγ⁢γsubscript𝜎𝛾𝛾italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-gamma italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{\gamma\gamma}; the structure function of the real photon, F2γsuperscriptsubscript𝐹2𝛾italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endF_{2}^{\gamma} (or equivalently the γ*⁢γsuperscript𝛾𝛾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma\gamma^{*}\gamma cross-section); and the total hadronic γ*⁢γ*superscript𝛾superscript𝛾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*} cross-section, σγ*⁢γ*subscript𝜎superscript𝛾superscript𝛾italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*}} respectively. Thus in principle it is possible to study diffraction continuously from the quasi-hadronic regime dominated by non-perturbative physics to the realm of perturbative QCD with either single or double hard scales.

The total hadronic γ⁢γ𝛾𝛾italic-gamma italic-gamma\gamma\gamma cross-section was measured at LEP in the ranges 5≤W≤1455𝑊145NUMBER:5 RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-W RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:1455\leq W\leq 145 GeV [1, 2] and 10≤W≤11010𝑊110NUMBER:10 RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-W RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:11010\leq W\leq 110 GeV [3], where W𝑊italic-WW is the photon-photon centre-of-mass energy (Fig. 1).

figure.figcaption: Figure 1: OPAL data at see=161-183subscript𝑠ee161183italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ee POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:161 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:183\sqrt{s}_{\rm ee}=161-183 GeV in comparison to the L3 data at see=130-161subscript𝑠ee130161italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ee POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:130 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:161\sqrt{s}_{\rm ee}=130-161 GeV (a), at see=183subscript𝑠ee183italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ee POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:183\sqrt{s}_{\rm ee}=183 GeV (b) and at see=189subscript𝑠ee189italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ee POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:189\sqrt{s}_{\rm ee}=189 GeV (c). In all cases PHOJET was used for the unfolding of detector effects. The continuous line is a fit to the OPAL data, the dashed line a fit to the L3 data at see=183-189subscript𝑠ee183189italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ee POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:183 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:189\sqrt{s}_{\rm ee}=183-189 GeV (see text).

div.p: Since the use of different Monte Carlo models (PYTHIA [4] or PHOJET [5]) for the unfolding of detector effects leads to significant shifts of the normalisation, the results of the two experiments are compared using only PHOJET for these corrections222The published OPAL data are given after averaging the PHOJET and the PYTHIA corrected results (Fig. 3)..

Both experiments have measured the high energy rise of the total cross-section typical for hadronic interactions. However a faster rise of the total γ⁢γ𝛾𝛾italic-gamma italic-gamma\gamma\gamma cross-section with W𝑊italic-WW compared to purely hadronic interactions has not been unambiguously observed. This faster rise is predicted by most models for γ⁢γ𝛾𝛾italic-gamma italic-gamma\gamma\gamma interactions.

To quantify this effect, both experiments have fitted a Donnachie-Landshoff parametrisation of the form σγ⁢γ=X⁢sϵ+Y⁢s-ηsubscript𝜎𝛾𝛾𝑋superscript𝑠italic-ϵ𝑌superscript𝑠𝜂italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-gamma italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-X italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-epsilon POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-Y italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus italic-eta POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sigma_{\gamma\gamma}=Xs^{\epsilon}+Ys^{-\eta} with η=0.34𝜂0.34italic-eta RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.34\eta=0.34. The results are ϵ=0.10±0.02italic-ϵplus-or-minus0.100.02italic-epsilon RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.10 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.02\epsilon=0.10\pm 0.02 (OPAL) and ϵ=0.22±0.02italic-ϵplus-or-minus0.220.02italic-epsilon RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.22 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:0.02\epsilon=0.22\pm 0.02 (L3), where the L3 fit uses only the preliminary data at see=183-189subscript𝑠ee183189italic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ee POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:183 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:189\sqrt{s}_{\rm ee}=183-189 GeV. The fitted curves are also shown in Fig. 1. The L3 result implies a significantly faster rise of the total γ⁢γ𝛾𝛾italic-gamma italic-gamma\gamma\gamma cross-section than in hadron-hadron scattering whereas the OPAL result is consistent with a typical value of ϵ≈0.08italic-ϵ0.08italic-epsilon RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.08\epsilon\approx 0.08 for a soft Pomeron.

The results are consistent in the kinematic region where the measurements of both experiments overlap. Some discrepancies seem to exist between the L3 measurements at different seesubscript𝑠eeitalic-square-root ARG:start italic-s ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ee POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sqrt{s}_{\rm ee}, both at low and at high W𝑊italic-WW. The data in the range W<10𝑊10italic-W RELOP:less-than NUMBER:10W<10 GeV also have large influence on the fitted value of ϵitalic-ϵitalic-epsilon\epsilon due to the large correlation between the Reggeon-Term Y𝑌italic-YY and ϵitalic-ϵitalic-epsilon\epsilon.

figure.figcaption: Figure 2: Left plot (L3): number of γ⁢γ→ρ0⁢X→𝛾𝛾superscript𝜌0𝑋italic-gamma italic-gamma ARROW:to italic-rho POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-X\gamma\gamma\to\rho^{0}X events as a function of the visible W𝑊italic-WW (Wvissubscript𝑊visitalic-W POSTSUBSCRIPT:start vis POSTSUBSCRIPT:endW_{\rm vis}). Right plots (OPAL): number of selected two-photon events in the range 6<Wvis<1206subscript𝑊vis120NUMBER:6 RELOP:less-than italic-W POSTSUBSCRIPT:start vis POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1206<W_{\rm vis}<120 GeV as a function of the maximum rapidity gap, Δ⁢ηmaxΔsubscript𝜂maxDelta italic-eta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start max POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta\eta_{\rm max}, between any two particles (tracks and calorimeter clusters). For the MC, the diffractive events (including quasi-elastic scattering) are shown separately.

div.p: The main problems of this measurement are the resolution effects in the reconstruction of W𝑊italic-WW from the hadronic final state and the small acceptance for events coming from soft diffractive or quasi-elastic processes (e.g. γ⁢γ→ρ⁢ρ→𝛾𝛾𝜌𝜌italic-gamma italic-gamma ARROW:to italic-rho italic-rho\gamma\gamma\to\rho\rho) which lead to the large model dependence for the final results. The W𝑊italic-WW resolution makes it necessary to use unfolding models which introduce large bin-to-bin correlations. The acceptance for soft diffractive and quasi-elastic processes is only 5-15%percentPOSTFIX:percent\%, depending on the W𝑊italic-WW range and on the MC model used [3]. For W>20𝑊20italic-W RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:20W>20 GeV the average polar angle of the pions in γ⁢γ→ρ⁢ρ→𝛾𝛾𝜌𝜌italic-gamma italic-gamma ARROW:to italic-rho italic-rho\gamma\gamma\to\rho\rho events is less than 100 mrad, well below the tracking coverage of the LEP detectors. L3 has therefore measured inclusive ρ𝜌italic-rho\rho production in γ⁢γ𝛾𝛾italic-gamma italic-gamma\gamma\gamma events for 3≤W≤103𝑊10NUMBER:3 RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-W RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:103\leq W\leq 10 GeV. In this W𝑊italic-WW region large discrepancies between the Monte Carlo models and the data are observed (Fig. 2). At higher W𝑊italic-WW OPAL has studied the maximum rapidity gap Δ⁢ηmaxΔsubscript𝜂maxDelta italic-eta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start max POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta\eta_{\rm max} between any two particles (tracks and calorimeter clusters) in an event. At high Δ⁢ηmaxΔsubscript𝜂maxDelta italic-eta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start max POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta\eta_{\rm max}, where diffractive events are expected to contribute, the data lie above the Monte Carlo models and PHOJET is closer to the data than PYTHIA.

Soft processes like quasi-elastic scattering (γ⁢γ→V⁢V→𝛾𝛾𝑉𝑉italic-gamma italic-gamma ARROW:to italic-V italic-V\gamma\gamma\to VV, where V𝑉italic-VV is a vector meson), single-diffractive scattering (γ⁢γ→V⁢X→𝛾𝛾𝑉𝑋italic-gamma italic-gamma ARROW:to italic-V italic-X\gamma\gamma\to VX, where X𝑋italic-XX is a low mass hadronic system) or double-diffractive scattering (γ⁢γ→X1⁢X2→𝛾𝛾subscript𝑋1subscript𝑋2italic-gamma italic-gamma ARROW:to italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\gamma\gamma\to X_{1}X_{2}) are modelled by both generators. The cross-sections are obtained by fitting a Regge parametrisation to pp, p⁢p¯p¯pATOM:p OVERACCENT:overline ARG:start ATOM:p ARG:end\mbox{p}\overline{\mbox{p}} and γ𝛾italic-gamma\gammap data and by assuming Regge factorisation, i.e. universal couplings of the Pomeron to the hadronic fluctuations of the photon. In both generators the quasi-elastic cross-section is about 5-6%5percent6NUMBER:5 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:6 POSTFIX:percent5-6\%, the single-diffractive cross-section about 8-12%8percent12NUMBER:8 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:12 POSTFIX:percent8-12\% and the double-diffractive cross-section about 3-4%3percent4NUMBER:3 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4 POSTFIX:percent3-4\% of σγ⁢γsubscript𝜎𝛾𝛾italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-gamma italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{\gamma\gamma} for W>10𝑊10italic-W RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:10W>10 GeV. In the γ⁢γ𝛾𝛾italic-gamma italic-gamma\gamma\gamma data no clear diffractive signal has yet been observed and it would be very useful to find experimental variables which could give a better discrimination between diffractive and non-diffractive events at LEP and which could be used to test the Monte Carlo models.

section.h2: 3 The hard Pomeron model and the dipole formalism

div.p: As the energies and virtualities available at LEP are comparatively moderate it is necessary to take into account diffractive and non-diffractive contributions. There are two main sources of the non-diffractive contributions: Reggeon exchange and the quark box diagram with pointlike couplings of the photon. In Regge language the latter gives rise to a fixed pole in the complex angular momentum plane, so it is not dual to Regge exchange and it is correct to add the two contributions. The box diagram is well defined [6]. The Regge contribution to F2γsuperscriptsubscript𝐹2𝛾italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endF_{2}^{\gamma} can be estimated [7] using the DGLAP evolved pion structure function and naive VMD. This can be extended to both the γ⁢γ𝛾𝛾italic-gamma italic-gamma\gamma\gamma and γ*⁢γ*superscript𝛾superscript𝛾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*} cross-sections assuming factorization [8]. In the dipole approach to the small-x𝑥italic-xx structure function of the proton it has become increasingly clear that the nominally perturbative regime still contains some non-perturbative contribution [9, 10, 11]. A specific model has been proposed in terms of two Pomerons [12, 13, 14]. This combines a hard Pomeron with an intercept of about 1.44 together with the soft Pomeron of hadronic physics with an intercept of about 1.08.

An analogous approach is that of [15] in which the hard Pomeron is modelled within the BFKL framework. A similar conclusion is reached, that for diffractive reactions on a hadronic target the purely perturbative regime is not reached until rather large values of Q2superscript𝑄2italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ^{2}.

Combining the dipole formalism with the two-Pomeron approach allows predictions to be made for the γ(*)⁢γ(*)superscript𝛾superscript𝛾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( MULOP:times CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( MULOP:times CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{(*)}\gamma^{(*)} cross-sections [8]. An appropriate model for soft Pomeron exchange is the eikonal approach [16] to high energy scattering. It is particularly suited to incorporate the non-perturbative aspects of QCD which are treated in the Model of the Stochastic Vacuum [17, 18, 19], which approximates the infrared part of QCD by a Gaussian stochastic process in the colour field strength. The two-Pomeron approach of [12] has been adapted to the MSV model in [20] and successfully tested for the photo- and electroproduction of vector mesons, and for the proton structure function over a wide range of x𝑥italic-xx and Q2superscript𝑄2italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ^{2}.

figure.figcaption: Figure 3: The total hadronic photon-photon cross-section σγ⁢γsubscript𝜎𝛾𝛾italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-gamma italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{\gamma\gamma} (in nb) as function of W𝑊italic-WW (in GeV).

Figure 4: The photon structure function F2γsuperscriptsubscript𝐹2𝛾italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endF_{2}^{\gamma} as function of x𝑥italic-xx. a) ⟨Q2⟩=1.9delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑄21.9OPEN:langle italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.9\langle Q^{2}\rangle=1.9 GeV22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2}, (L3: triangles, OPAL: diamonds and boxes); b) ⟨Q2⟩≈15delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑄215OPEN:langle italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:15\langle Q^{2}\rangle\approx 15 GeV22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2}, (ALEPH: stars, L3: triangles, OPAL: diamonds and boxes).

Figure 5: The virtual photon cross-section σγ*⁢γ*subscript𝜎superscript𝛾superscript𝛾italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*}} in nb. L3 data points are shown.

div.p: With all parameters determined from hadronic scattering and deep inelastic scattering, in principle the model can then predict all the γ(*)⁢γ(*)superscript𝛾superscript𝛾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( MULOP:times CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start OPEN:( MULOP:times CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{(*)}\gamma^{(*)} cross-sections [8]. The only caveat is that the Pomeron contribution to σγ⁢γsubscript𝜎𝛾𝛾italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-gamma italic-gamma POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{\gamma\gamma} is rather sensitive to the effective light quark mass mqsubscript𝑚qitalic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start q POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{\rm q} entering the photon wave function, varying as ∼1/mq4similar-toabsent1superscriptsubscript𝑚q4RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\sim 1/m_{\rm q}^{4}. This is illustrated in Figs. 3a and b which show separately the L3 [1, 2] and OPAL [3] data and the Pomeron model with mq=210subscript𝑚q210italic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start q POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:210m_{\rm q}=210 MeV and 200 MeV respectively, together with the other contributions to the total cross-section. These values of mqsubscript𝑚qitalic-m POSTSUBSCRIPT:start q POSTSUBSCRIPT:endm_{\rm q} are within the range previously determined, and the choice does not affect the predictions away from Q2=0superscript𝑄20italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0Q^{2}=0. Comparison of the predictions with F2γsuperscriptsubscript𝐹2𝛾italic-F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endF_{2}^{\gamma} at ⟨Q2⟩=1.9delimited-⟨⟩superscript𝑄21.9OPEN:langle italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.9\langle Q^{2}\rangle=1.9 and 1515NUMBER:1515 GeV22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2} are shown in Figs. 4 a and b respectively. They clearly provide a satisfactory description of the data. However comparison with σγ*⁢γ*subscript𝜎superscript𝛾superscript𝛾italic-sigma POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\sigma_{\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*}} is much less successful as is evident in Figs. 5a and b, for which ⟨Q12⟩=⟨Q22⟩=3.5delimited-⟨⟩superscriptsubscript𝑄12delimited-⟨⟩superscriptsubscript𝑄223.5OPEN:langle italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle RELOP:equals OPEN:langle italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle RELOP:equals NUMBER:3.5\langle Q_{1}^{2}\rangle=\langle Q_{2}^{2}\rangle=3.5 and 14 GeV22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2} respectively.

The significance of these results is that a well-tried model of diffraction which successfully describes high-energy hadronic interactions, vector meson photo- and electroproduction, deep inelastic scattering at small x𝑥italic-xx, the real γ⁢γ𝛾𝛾italic-gamma italic-gamma\gamma\gamma cross-section and the structure function of the real photon fails to predict correctly the γ*⁢γ*superscript𝛾superscript𝛾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*} cross-section even at quite modest photon virtualities. This is clearly due to the fact that, uniquely among these various processes, the γ*⁢γ*superscript𝛾superscript𝛾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*} interaction involves two small dipoles. It emphasizes the importance of the γ*⁢γ*superscript𝛾superscript𝛾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*} cross-section as a probe of the dynamics of the perturbative hard Pomeron.

section.h2: 4 𝜸*⁢𝜸*superscript𝜸superscript𝜸bold-italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:bold-times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end bold-italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:bold-times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*} scattering in the BFKL formalism

div.p: The application of the BFKL formalism to γ*⁢γ*superscript𝛾superscript𝛾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*} scattering has been considered by [21-26]. In the BFKL formalism there is a problem at LLO in setting the two mass scales on which the cross-section depends: the mass μ2superscript𝜇2italic-mu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\mu^{2} at which the strong coupling αssubscript𝛼𝑠italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\alpha_{s} is evaluated and the mass Qs2superscriptsubscript𝑄𝑠2italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ_{s}^{2} which provides

figure.figcaption: Figure 6: Cross-section for the process e+⁢e-→e+⁢e-⁢γ*⁢γ*→e+⁢e-→superscriptesuperscriptesuperscriptesuperscriptesuperscript𝛾superscript𝛾→superscriptesuperscripteATOM:e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ATOM:e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARROW:to ATOM:e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ATOM:e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARROW:to ATOM:e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ATOM:e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\mbox{e}^{+}\mbox{e}^{-}\to\mbox{e}^{+}\mbox{e}^{-}\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*}\to% \mbox{e}^{+}\mbox{e}^{-} hadrons as a function of Y≈ln⁡(W2/Q12⁢Q22)𝑌superscript𝑊2superscriptsubscript𝑄12superscriptsubscript𝑄22italic-Y RELOP:approximately-equals OPFUNCTION:natural-logarithm OPEN:( italic-W POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)Y\approx\ln(W^{2}/Q_{1}^{2}Q_{2}^{2}) (for exact kinematic cuts see [28] and [29]).

div.p: the scale for the high energy logarithms. The result is very sensitive to these parameters, and Brodsky et al [23, 24] showed that changing μ2→4⁢μ2→superscript𝜇24superscript𝜇2italic-mu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARROW:to NUMBER:4 italic-mu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\mu^{2}\to 4\mu^{2} or Qs2→Qs2/4→superscriptsubscript𝑄𝑠2superscriptsubscript𝑄𝑠24italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARROW:to italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:4Q_{s}^{2}\to Q_{s}^{2}/4 alters the predicted cross-section by factors of ∼1/4similar-toabsent14RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide NUMBER:4\sim 1/4 or ∼4similar-toabsent4RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:4\sim 4 respectively in a typical LEP experiment. An additional uncertainty is due to the correct treatment of the production of massive charm quarks.

In an attempt to overcome the scale problem, Boonekamp et al [25] take a phenomenological approach to estimate the NNLO effects, making use of a fit [27] to the proton structure function using the QCD dipole picture of BFKL dynamics. This reduces both the size of the BFKL cross-section and its energy dependence. Fig. 6 shows the preliminary OPAL measurement of the double-tag e+FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:plus FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{+}e-FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-} cross-section in the range Q12≈Q22≈5-25superscriptsubscript𝑄12superscriptsubscript𝑄22525italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals italic-Q POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:5 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:25Q_{1}^{2}\approx Q_{2}^{2}\approx 5-25 GeV22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2} [28] compared to the LO BFKL calculation and to the HO model of Boonekamp et al. [25]. The cross-section predicted by PHOJET [5] is also shown. The L3 collaboration has extracted the γ*⁢γ*superscript𝛾superscript𝛾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*} cross-section using the photon flux for transverse photons (Fig. 6) [29]. The QPM part (box diagram) has been subtracted (the unsubtracted cross-section is shown in Fig. 5). The L3 data is compared to a LO BFKL prediction and to the two-gluon exchange cross-section (here called one-gluon) based on Ref. [24] and to a fit of the hard Pomeron intercept. A calculation [26] of subleading corrections to the BFKL equation shows that these are significant at LEP energies, and with the inclusion of the soft Pomeron a reasonable description of the L3 data is obtained.

Both experiments observe that the cross-section predicted by PHOJET, which does not contain BFKL effects, is consistent with the data within the large experimental errors, whereas LO BFKL predictions overestimate the γ*⁢γ*superscript𝛾superscript𝛾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*} cross-section by a large factor. However, the large theoretical uncertainties discussed above need to be taken into account.

In the last year difficulties have emerged with the application of the Altarelli-Parisi equation to the evolution of the proton structure function at small x𝑥italic-xx and with the BFKL equation. These are summarised in [30]. One of the questions is whether intrinsically non-perturbative contributions are involved, even at quite large Q2superscript𝑄2italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ^{2}, because of the intrinsically non-perturbative target. This complication is in principle avoided in γ*⁢γ*superscript𝛾superscript𝛾italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-gamma POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\gamma^{*}\gamma^{*} reactions as both are dominated at large Q2superscript𝑄2italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ^{2} by the perturbative part of the photon wave function. This may be happening at quite modest values of Q2superscript𝑄2italic-Q POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endQ^{2}, providing LEP with an excellent opportunity to clarify this question.
